title-group.article-title: Management strategies on the industrialization road of state-of- the-art technologies for e-waste recycling: the case study of electrostatic separation—a review

abstract.p: Electronic waste (e-waste) management is pressing as global production has increased significantly in the past few years and is rising continuously at a fast rate. Many countries are facing hazardous e-waste mountains, most of which are disposed of by backyard recyclers, creating serious threats to public health and ecosystems. Industrialization of state-of-the-art recycling technologies is imperative to enhance the comprehensive utilization of resources and to protect the environment. This article aims to provide an overview of management strategies solving the crucial problems during the process of industrialization. A typical case study of electrostatic separation for recycling waste printed circuit boards was discussed in terms of parameters optimization, materials flow control, noise assessment, risk assessment, economic evaluation and social benefits analysis. The comprehensive view provided by the review could be helpful to the progress of the e-waste recycling industry.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Since the mid-1990s, electronic waste (e-waste) has been recognized as the fastest growing category of waste (Ogunseitan, 2009; Ongondo et al., 2011). To cope with the specter of hazardous e-waste mountains, which have serious consequences for the environment and public health, two primary management strategies are implemented: (i) to restrict the use of certain hazardous materials in electrical and electronic equipment, the philosophy of which is controlling pollution from source according to clean production principle; and (ii) to develop and promote green technologies for recycling e-waste, the philosophy of which is dealing with wastes in an environmental friendly way.

Take China as an example: 2.3 million tonnes of e-waste were generated domestically and 28 million tonnes were imported from developed countries in 2010. However, approximately 21 million tonnes was disposed of improperly by backyard recyclers and only 9.3 million tonnes was handled through state-of-the-art industrial recycling systems (UNEP, 2010). In this context, China enacted the Regulations for the Administration of the Recovery and Disposal of Waste Electrical and Electronic Products to promote circular economic development (MIIT, 2011). Processing of e-waste shall meet requirements on comprehensive utilization of resources, environmental protection and human health of the nation. Therefore, industrialization of state-of-the-art recycling technologies is imperative, particularly in developing countries.

State-of-the-art recycling technologies have the following characteristics (Zhou and Xu, 2012): high disposal rate, high recovery rate, high purity of products, high added value final products and high degree of automation. Significantly, during the process of industrialization some crucial questions should be answered: How to optimize and adjust the technical parameters?; How to control the materials flow in the recycling system?; What kind of environmental impact do the technologies themselves produce?; Is the recycling system economically feasible?; What about the social benefits?.

In order to promote the industrialization of state-of-the-art recycling technologies, this article reviews the management strategies in response to vital problems, including parameters optimization, materials flow control, noise assessment, risk assessment, economic evaluation and social benefits analysis. They are presented as a case study of electrostatic separation for recycling wasted printed circuit boards (PCBs).

sec.title: Electrostatic separation
sec.p: Electrostatic separation is the selective sorting of charged or polarized bodies under the action of an electric field (Ralston, 1961). The roll-type corona electrostatic separator is a classic machine for recycling waste PCBs owing to the possibility of controlling the output of the process by regulating input parameters (Dascalescu et al., 2005). It has a grounded rotating roll electrode and other active electrodes (corona-electrostatic) connected to a direct current (DC) high-voltage supply, as shown in Figure 1. The electric feeder ensures a monolayer of granular material on the surface of the rotating roll. The high-intensity electric field is generated between the grounded and active electrodes.

caption.p: Schematic representation of roll-type corona electrostatic separator.

sec.title: Charge mechanism
sec.p: There exist two charging mechanisms in the separation process: corona charge and induction charge (seen in Figure 2). More specifically, the air around the corona electrode connected to a high-voltage supply is ionized and the ion current is generated between the corona electrode and grounded electrode. During the transit time, the particles are subjected to ion bombardment (corona discharge). However, the conductive particles discharge rapidly to the grounded electrode. Simultaneously, the particles also charge by electrostatic induction. The electric field extracts the charge carriers from the electrode and transfers them to the particles (Dascalescu et al., 1994; Lindley and Rowson, 1997).

caption.p: Charge mechanisms of electrostatic separation: (a) corona charge process; (b) induction charge process.

sec.title: Separation principle
sec.p: The movement behavior of nonconductive and conductive particles is different because of their extreme difference in the electrical conductivity, which provides an excellent condition for the implementation of the corona electrostatic separation (CES) (Cui and Forssberg, 2003). The particulate mixture to be separated is fed onto the surface of the roll electrode. They rotate with the roll electrode at a certain velocity and pass through the electric field. Nonconductive particles are charged by ion bombardment with the same polarity as the high-voltage electrode. They are not affected by the electrostatic induction. Therefore, the nonconductive particles are pinned to the surface of the rotating roll electrode as a result of the electric image force. A brush is needed to remove them from the roll electrode and, finally, they are collected in the left-side holding tank (seen in Figure 1). For conductive particles, they charge by electrostatic induction and are attracted to the electrostatic electrode. Conductive particles are not affected by the corona field. When the electrical force and the centrifugal force exerting on them equal to the opposite gravity force, conductive particles detach from the roll electrode and fall into the right-side holding tank. Consequently, the particulate mixtures are separated successfully (Dascalescu et al., 1994; Tilmatine et al., 2009).

sec.title: Electrostatic separation for recycling wasted PCBs
sec.p: Huge amounts of waste PCBs resulting from dramatically increased e-waste present a new environmental challenge. Indeed, the recycling of waste PCBs has captured much attention from both the scientific community and industry (Huang et al., 2009). In fact, waste PCBs are regarded as an urban mine because of their high content of noble and rare metals (Li et al., 2007a; Zhou and Qiu, 2010). Nevertheless, the crude processing of waste PCBs which contain plenty of toxic substances [brominated flame retardants, heavy metals, polyvinylchloride (PVC) plastic, etc.] may create considerable adverse effects on public health and ecosystems (Duan and Li, 2011; Stone, 2009). Therefore, the treatment of waste PCBs is an important subject not only for valuable materials recovery, but also for environmental protection.

Generally, the recycling methods of waste PCBs can be summarized as pyrometallurgy, hydrometallurgy, biological treatment and mechanical processing, as shown in Table 1 (Hall and Williams, 2007; Havlik et al., 2011; Long et al., 2010; Yoo et al., 2009; Zhu et al., 2011). Technology industrialization is the bottleneck of all methods. The vast majority of PCBs wastes is subjected to a mechanical treatment, a promising method without secondary pollution. The mechanical process consists of two basic stages: liberation and separation. The key to the process is materials separation (Li et al., 2008a). As an environmentally benign approach, CES has already proven its feasibility in the recycling of metals and nonmetals from waste PCBs (Li et al., 2007b).

caption.p: Recycling methods of waste printed circuit boards.

sec.p: CES is a typical multifactorial process. From the point of practical production, identification of the optimal operating condition is a crucial issue. Its efficiency depends on the applied voltage level, the separator configuration, the material characteristics, the feed rate, the environmental conditions and so on (Mihailescu et al., 2002; Wu et al., 2008a). The roll type corona electrostatic separator can be used effectively to recycle conductive particles and nonconductive particles by optimizing these variables (Li et al., 2008a; Wu et al., 2008b).

sec.title: Linear interaction modeling for optimization
sec.p: To determine the optimum condition of the technology is the basis of its industrial application. The optimization of the multifactorial process usually needs a large number of tests. Fortunately, the experimental design techniques make it possible to optimize the process with minimal effort (Mihailescu et al., 2002). More specifically, the factors and the responses are identified and an appropriate design for experiments is chosen. Then, the responses of the process are measured in a selected number of states. Finally, an optimum is computed by the mathematical model established on the basis of the tests.

A mathematical model can be used to describe the relationship between the factors and the separation efficiency. In many cases interactions exist. Linear interaction models were established by Taguchi design (Dascalecu et al., 2002), fractional factorial design (Mihailescu et al., 2002) and full fractional design (Medles et al., 2007a) to optimize the electrostatic separation process for recycling electric cable wastes (size always greater 1.0 mm). These studies revealed that design of experiment methodology is an efficient tool for the optimization of electrostatic separation processes. However, comminuted PCBs, which have a size of <0.6 mm to ensure the complete liberation of metals and nonmetals, are very different (Li et al., 2007a). Owing to the lower resolution of Taguchi design, a linear interaction model has been built for the process of waste PCB recycling by a fractional factorial design (2v1-5) (Wu et al., 2008a). Six parameters were considered as notable factors: U (kV), applied voltage; n (rpm), roll speed; a1 (o) and s1 (mm), position of the corona electrode; a2 (o) and s2 (mm), position of the electrostatic electrode. Individual effect experiments showed that s2 was a minor factor, the value of which was fixed. The responses were the mass of middling fraction (M), conductor fraction (C), and nonconductor fraction (NC) respectively. Thirty-two tests were performed with one replication for each test.

The experimental results were analyzed by Minitab 15.0 (Minitab Inc., State College, PA, USA), an excellent experimental design and statistical software. Three linear interaction models which omitted the factors and interactions without statistic significance were built (Wu et al., 2008a):

The main effects and interactions plot of factors are shown in Figure 3 (Wu et al., 2008a). The high voltage, roll speed, angle position of the corona and electrostatic electrode had a larger coefficient in the models and greater slope in the main effect plot, indicating that they are key factors. For C, a stronger electrostatic field would be produced by a higher voltage. Also, a more extensive electrostatic field would be created with a larger space between the two electrodes. The separation of conductive particles could be enhanced if the roll speed was higher, resulting in a stronger centrifugal force. Moreover, the interactions Ua1 and Ua2 were examined. It is noteworthy that their signs were contrary to the a1 and a2. This phenomenon indicated that the mass of C increased with the increase of the voltage level only in a finite range. According to model 1, the optimum settings for maximizing the mass of C were U=30 kV, n=80 rpm, s1=60 mm, a2=75o, s2=90 mm. The analysis of the results of M and NC are the same as the C. It is interesting that good results can always be achieved with a larger a2. Hence, a2 could be fixed in the following experiments.

sec.title: Response surface modeling for optimization
sec.p: However, the linear interaction model would be inaccuracy if there are curves between the response and the factors. Hence, it is necessary to build nonlinear models for the waste PCB recycling process. Response surface methodology (RSM) is a convenient method of optimizing multifactorial process. Research has shown that RSM is an effective tool for the development of a new electrostatic separation application (Dascalecu et al., 2004).

Some less important factors (s1, s2, and a2) were screened by the fraction factorial design (Wu et al., 2008a). Consequently, the U, n, a1 were considered to be the three most important factors. For further investigation, Qin et al. (2009) employed a three-factor central composite design to analyze the second order effects of factors. The responses were the mass of middling fraction (M), conductor fraction (C), and nonconductor fraction (NC) respectively.

Seventeen tests were conducted and the results were analyzed by Minitab 15.0. The response C here is taken as an example. The quadratic models which omitted the factors and interactions without statistic significance were set up (Qin et al., 2009):

The regression analysis showed that U, n and the interaction Ua1 were statistically significant. Remarkably, the quadratic coefficient of U is significant. However, the variance analysis indicated that the linear effect was a little more significant than the interaction effect and the quadratic effect. Figure 4 illustrates the contour plot and surface plot of the quadratic model for C. It is seen that the voltage level (28–29 kV) brings about excellent results when the roll speed is in a high level. The analysis of the results of M and NC are the same as the C.

sec.title: Robust design for optimization
sec.p: In practice some factors regarded as design factors are easy to control. They affect, essentially, the process. Other factors, which are considered to be noise factors, are hard to control. The robust design is a form of optimization. It could find the conditions where the response is still acceptable, even when noise factors, such as variations in materials and environmental conditions, vary (Dascalescu et al., 2005; Medles et al., 2007b).

Nonconductive powder (NP), produced during the grinding process, will bring about obvious surface phenomena in the separation process (Wu et al., 2009). In addition, the superficial moisture of feeding materials can affect the nonconductive particles’ conductivity and charge when they pass through the electrical field. Indeed, the two factors influence the separation efficiency and they are difficult to control at the industrial scale. In this context, Hou et al., (2010) employed a robust design to minimize the negative effect of these noise factors. U and n are used as design factors. The NP content and the relative humidity (RH) are identified as noise factors. The design factors and noise factors are arranged as inner and outer orthogonals respectively. As presented in Figure 5, the design number was 5*5=25. Furthermore, two more experiments were done in the central point to verify the reproducibility of experiments.

From the model we can conclude that the separation process will be more robust with a lower voltage level and a higher roll speed. The optimum voltage level and the roll speed could be 25 kV and 80 rpm respectively.

The experimental results can be analyzed by statistical analysis software and models can be set up for interpretation, prediction and optimization. This methodology can be applied to other multifactorial processes.

sec.title: Technology industrialization
sec.p: The technology industrialization is the final goal of the research. Li and Xu (2010) established a set of automatic lines for recycling waste PCB at an industrial scale. Figure 6 presents the engineering schematic plan. It contains three parts: multiple scraping, pneumatic separation and dust precipitation, and electrostatic separation. Wasted PCBs were scrapped by a crusher and grinded into particles. After scrapping, metals and nonmetals were liberated. The following pneumatic separation acted as a pretreatment process for electrostatic separation. Fine particles that influenced the charge of metal particles were separated (Wu et al., 2009) and dust was collected by a bag-type dust collector. The coarse particles then were separated by the electrostatic separator.

caption.p: Engineering schematic plan of the automatic line. (Reproduced from Li J and Xu Z (2010) Environmental friendly automatic Line for recovering metal from waste printed circuit boards. Environmental Science & Technology 44: 1418–1423 with permission from the American Chemical Society).

sec.p: The productivity of the recycling system can reach 600 kg h-1. And the metal recovery rate can reach 95% (Li and Xu, 2010). The middlings were delivered back to the electrostatic separator for further separation. Because the components of PCBs were complex, Zhan and Xu (2009) purified and recycled copper, zinc, lead, cadmium and bismuth from metal products by vacuum metallurgy. For nonmetal products, they could be reused by producing wood plastic composite (Guo et al., 2010). The metal and nonmetal products were all recycled.

sec.title: Substance flow control
sec.p: There are some engineering problems after the automatic line goes into operation: (i) the contradiction between insufficient liberation and over-pulverizing of materials; (ii) material plugging; and (iii) equipment fever. Waste PCB particle grinding and cyclic system classification (seen in Figure 6), the most important part of the automatic production line, decides the efficiency of the whole production line. In order to better control the cyclic system, a model for computing the process of the system by a matrix analysis method was established (Yang and Xu, 2011). MATLAB software was employed for programming. During the process, material flow and particle size distribution could be elucidated. To verify the effectiveness of the model, 1000 kg of waste PCBs was used for experiments. The experimental results showed good agreement with the simulating results. This model paves the way for automatic control of the waste PCB recycling system.

sec.title: Noise monitoring and risk assessment
sec.p: Work safety analyses are needed at plants and sites (Ettala et al., 1989). On one hand, a high level of noise may be generated by the recycling system. Noise pollution, a category of environmental pollution, frequently causes the appearance of professional disorders of workers in industry (Choi et al., 2012). In almost all countries there are laws that regulate the maximum value of noise in workshops (Zunjic, 2012). Hence, it is necessary to conduct noise assessment for the automatic line and to reduce the exposure of workers to high noise levels. Xue et al., (2012) monitored the noise generated by each machine in the workshop. The results suggested that the noise level exceeded the Occupational Safety and Health Standards [the maximum value is 90 dB (A) for employees who work for 8 h per day in the workshop]. For the purpose of noise reduction, sound insulation was used by controlling noise in the transmission path. The design calculation of the noise insulator is shown in Table 3. Performance evaluation of the noise insulator indicated that noise with a frequency of 500–1000 Hz was reduced effectively. The engineering measures for noise reduction are feasible and noise will not cause harm to human health in this recycling system workshop (Xue et al., 2012). It can be seen as a model case for noise monitoring and evaluation in a similar workshop.

sec.p: On the other hand, dust containing metals such as lead, chromium, copper and cadmium may be released into the workshop during operation. Unfortunately, exposure to those heavy metals will possibly bring about serious health risks (Hengstler et al., 2003; Li et al., 2011). In this context, particle concentrations in the workshop were monitored and heavy metal distribution characteristics were investigated (Xue et al., 2012). The mass concentration of total suspended particulates (TSP) with a diameter <100 μm) was 282.6 μg/m and the mass concentration of the particulate matter (PM10) with a diameter <10 μm was 202.0 μg/m. It indicated that particles in the ambience of the automatic line were mainly fine particles. The mass concentrations of heavy metals trend in TSP and PM10 were the same: lead > copper > chromium > cadmium. Risk assessment results showed that there were no noncancerous effects for copper, chromium and cadmium. Remarkably, the hazard quotient of lead by ingestion was 1.41, which suggested that adverse effects were possible. Hence, wearing dust protection masks was advised. From the standpoint of exposure pathways, ingestion made the highest contribution, followed by dermal contact and inhalation. The risk assessment provides important information for the industrialization of the technology, and the methodology can be applied to other plants that engage in e-waste management.

sec.title: Economic evaluation and social benefits assessment
sec.p: Economic evaluation is also an important approach that can be used for waste management decision support (Finnveden et al., 2007). To analyze a project from the angle of engineering economy is an important part of feasibility analysis. Xue et al., (2011) carried out research focusing on the economic performance of the recycling system. The profit ratio of production is 24.65% and profit ratio of investment is 63.08%. The pay-back period is 2.52 years and the internal rate of return can reach 43.00%. Sales revenue is the most sensitive factor. If sales revenue increased by 10%, the net present value would increase to 70.83% and the pay-back period would decrease by 28.97%.

Considering the potential impact caused by the recycling system, mineral resource consumption, energy consumption, water consumption and carbon dioxide emissions during the process were calculated (Xue et al., 2011). The results were compared with typical copper refining processes (pyrometallurgy and biological extraction method), as shown in Figure 7. Mineral resource consumption decreased by 97.48% compared with pyrometallurgy, and 97.72% compared with the biological extraction method. For energy consumption it decreased by 85.03% compared with pyrometallurgy, and 60.96% compared with the biological extraction method. For water consumption it decreased by 94.05% compared with pyrometallurgy, and 54.04% compared with the biological extraction method. For carbon dioxide emissions it decreased by 88.43% compared with pyrometallurgy, and 69.15% compared the with biological extraction method. In general, this physical recycling system can be applied widely in industry and have good benefits for society. The recycling system is an advance on the angle of economic and social benefits in the waste PCB recycling industry, which provides a progressive method for better e-waste management.

caption.p: Social and environmental benefits comparison between copper smelting and recycling (source: Xue et al., 2011).

sec.title: Management strategy framework for technology industrialization
sec.p: To better understand the management strategies before and after industrialization of electrostatic separation technology, a whole framework was summarized, as shown in Figure 8. From the viewpoint of theory, the charge mechanisms and the separation principle were analyzed. From the viewpoint of technology, the main effects, interactions, quadratic effects and robust conditions were identified. In addition, a substance flow control model was established by matrix analysis method. From the viewpoint of environmental protection, environmental impact factors (noise, dust and heavy metals) were evaluated by monitoring, analysis and risk assessment. From the viewpoint of economic benefits, investment analysis, break-even analysis and sensitivity analysis were carried out. From the viewpoint of social benefits, resources consumption, energy consumption, water consumption and carbon dioxide emissions were calculated. The methodology might be applied to other technologies or methods as many technologies face the challenge of industrialization.

caption.p: Management strategy framework for electronic waste recycling technology industrialization.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: On the one hand e-waste is a rich resource owing to its high content of valuable metals. On the other hand hazardous materials in e-waste can cause far-reaching toxic pollution if they are disposed of via crude methods. E-waste management has captured much attention from the government, the scientific community, enterprise and backyard recyclers. At present, the production of e-waste is enormous. Nevertheless, only a small amount is handled in an environmentally-friendly manner. The industrialization of state-of-the-art technologies has a long way to go. Moreover, there exist many vital problems, including parameters optimization, materials flow control, noise assessment, risk assessment, economic evaluation and social benefits analysis on the road of industrialization. The purpose of this study is to provide the industry with the management solutions to overcome these challenges.

New technologies and technologies that are applied in a new field will experience a process of industrialization. The management strategy framework for technology industrialization can be divided into technology, environment, economy and society aspects. This framework might be expanded to other technologies.
